original_prompt: In this task, you will be shown a conversation and a question. You should categorize the question into matching, summary, logic, arithmetic and, commonsense groups. Matching is a question entailed or paraphrased by exactly one sentence in a dialogue. The answer can be extracted from the same sentence. Questions that cannot be answered by the surface meaning of a single sentence belong to the reasoning category. We further define summary, logic, arithmetic and, commonsense subcategories. Answering summary questions requires the whole picture of dialogue, such as the topic of dialogue and the relation between speakers. We require logical reasoning to answer logical questions. in arithmetic questions Inferring the answer requires arithmetic knowledge. To answer commonsense questions, besides the textual information in the dialogue, we also require additional commonsense knowledge that cannot be obtained from the dialogue. Note that a question can be in more than one group. "W" and "M" in the conversations stand for "woman" and "man".
generated_prompts: In this task, you will be given a conversation and a question. You should categorize the question into one of the following groups: matching, summary, logic, arithmetic, or commonsense. Matching questions are entailed or paraphrased by exactly one sentence in the dialogue, and the answer can be extracted from that same sentence. Questions that cannot be answered by the surface meaning of a single sentence belong in the reasoning category. The summary, logic, arithmetic, and commonsense subcategories require, respectively, that the whole picture of the dialogue be taken into account, logical reasoning, arithmetic knowledge, or commonsense knowledge in addition to the textual information in the dialogue. Note that a question can be in more than one group. "W" and "M" in the conversations stand for "woman" and "man".

In this task, you will be given a conversation and a question. You should categorize the question into one of the following groups: matching, summary, logic, arithmetic, and commonsense. A matching question is one that is entailed or paraphrased by exactly one sentence in the dialogue, and the answer can be extracted from that sentence. A summary question requires the whole picture of the dialogue in order to be answered, such as the topic of the dialogue and the relation between the speakers. A logic question requires logical reasoning to answer. An arithmetic question requires arithmetic knowledge to answer. A commonsense question requires knowledge that cannot be obtained from the dialogue, in addition to the textual information in the dialogue. Note that a question can be in more than one group. "W" and "M" in the conversations stand for "woman" and "man".

In this task, you will be given a conversation and a question. You will need to categorize the question into one of the following groups: matching, summary, logic, arithmetic, or commonsense. Matching questions are those that can be answered by a single sentence in the dialogue. Summary questions require an understanding of the entire conversation, including the topic and the relationship between the speakers. Logic questions require logical reasoning. Arithmetic questions require knowledge of arithmetic. Commonsense questions require knowledge that is not obtained from the conversation itself, but from general commonsense. Note that a question can belong to more than one group.

In this task, you will be shown a conversation and a question. Your task is to categorize the question into matching, summary, logic, arithmetic, and commonsense groups. Matching is a question entailed or paraphrased by exactly one sentence in a dialogue. The answer can be extracted from the same sentence. Questions that cannot be answered by the surface meaning of a single sentence belong to the reasoning category. We further define summary, logic, arithmetic, and commonsense subcategories. Answering summary questions requires the whole picture of dialogue, such as the topic of dialogue and the relation between speakers. We require logical reasoning to answer logical questions. In arithmetic questions, inferring the answer requires arithmetic knowledge. To answer commonsense questions, besides the textual information in the dialogue, we also require additional commonsense knowledge that cannot be obtained from the dialogue. Note that a question can be in more than one group. "W" and "M" in the conversations stand for "woman" and "man".

In this task, you will be given a conversation and a question. You will need to categorize the question into one of the following groups: matching, summary, logic, arithmetic, and commonsense. A question is considered to be matching if it can be entailed or paraphrased by exactly one sentence in the dialogue, and the answer can be extracted from that sentence. A question is considered to be summary if it requires the whole picture of the dialogue in order to be answered, such as the topic of the dialogue and the relation between the speakers. A question is considered to be logical if it requires logical reasoning to be answered. A question is considered to be arithmetic if inferring the answer requires arithmetic knowledge. A question is considered to be commonsense if, in addition to the textual information in the dialogue, answering the question also requires additional commonsense knowledge that cannot be obtained from the dialogue. Note that a question can be in more than one group.
